review.title: Judgment Aggregation in Multi-Agent Argumentation
review.abstract: Given a set of conflicting arguments, there can exist multiple plausible opinions about which arguments should be accepted, rejected, or deemed undecided. We study the problem of how multiple such judgments can be aggregated. We define the problem by adapting various classical social-choice-theoretic properties for the argumentation domain. We show that while argument-wise plurality voting satisfies many properties, it fails to guarantee the \emph{collective rationality} of the outcome, and struggles with ties. We then present more general results, proving multiple impossibility results on the existence of \emph{any} good aggregation operator. After characterising the sufficient and necessary conditions for satisfying collective rationality, we study whether restricting the domain of argument-wise plurality voting to classical semantics allows us to escape the impossibility result. We close by listing graph-theoretic restrictions under which argument-wise plurality rule does produce collectively rational outcomes. In addition to identifying fundamental barriers to collective argument evaluation, our results open up the door for a new research agenda for the argumentation and computational social choice communities.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: An important milestone in the development of argumentation in AI is Dung's ground-breaking framework [15], known as the abstract argumentation framework (AAF), but arguments are seen as abstract entities (a proposition A), with a binary denial relationship about them. Denial relationship captures the fact that one argument should somehow be accepted or undermines another. This view of reasoning allows for high-level analysis, while abstraction takes place away from the internal structure of individual arguments. Dung's approach sets out arguments and a denial relationship, a rule defining which arguments should be accepted. Often, there are several reasonable ways in which an agent can evaluate a given argumentation structure (e.g. by accepting only conflict-free, self-defending arguments). Each possible assessment corresponds to a so-called extension or labeling [8, 9].

sections.heading: 10 Discussion
sections.text: This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the socio-theoretical aspects of Dung's highly influential argumentation semantics. Argumentation-based semantics have been compared mainly on the basis of the way they deal with specific benchmark problems that reflect specific logical structures from the point of view of a single omniscient observer. Our work can be seen as a contribution in this direction by focusing on questions of multi-agent preferences. Caminada and Pigozzi [10] are the closest work on this paper. In their work, they present three aggregation operators, namely skeptical, creative and super-credit systems. Although the operators violate collective rationality, they violate independence.
